This is big--and remember that the minipill can also help manage heavy periods. 

So much of period pain and suffering can be reduced with effective treatment. Talk to a doctor if you're able. Find one that takes girls' and women's pain seriously. But don't suffer unnecessarily.

Students! Do not uncritically use Stata's default output for sum to make tables in papers!

Ex: the min & max may not be interesting stats for the reader. And when they are interesting, often a distribution figure would be better.

And don't get me started on "obs" columns where every # is the same.

In some good news, most (some say ~all) of the increase in the 2000s is due to the staggered rollout of a new way of counting maternal deaths: pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32510309/
I’ve loved being part of the Census Tree project!! New NBER working paper out today demonstrates some of the great findings available in this rich dataset!

This work is made possible by the Census Tree, which Joe Price, Adrian Haws, Haley Wilbert, and I worked to create (with many other contributors at the BYU Record Linking Lab and at Notre Dame). Find out how we did it and access the data for yourself at censustree.org!

Overall, our results show that when you include the full population (not just white men), and account for measurement error in the parent's status, the story is that intergenerational transmission was very strong in the past in the U.S., but decreasing over time:

Meanwhile, the high persistance (low mobility) for single women is due to high rates of labor force participation for single Black women, who also had low mobility. Persistence estimates increase a lot when Black women are included in the sample:

The result for married men and women suggests a high level of assortative mating, which we also show. Our ability to account for measurement error using IV leads to much higher estimates of assortative mating than in prior work.

The rich data allow us to address selection and measurement error issues, and to look at mobility by gender, race, and marital status. Some key findings: mobility was very similar for married women and men, but single women were less mobile than single men:

In our new NBER WP, we estimate historical intergenerational mobility for men **and women** using hundreds of millions of census-to-census links from the Census Tree. 🧵 👇https://www.nber.org/papers/w31918

with Zach Ward, Joe Price, & Haley Wilbert
Me, to my children making demands for what they’d like to eat tomorrow:
Please can we make it a norm that you should say *where you obtained the data* in a paper. Not just what the data is, but where and how you accessed it.
